issue.title: Fix `SyntaxWarning` in Python 3.12
issue.body:
The line containing `(¯\_(ツ)_/¯)` makes Python issue a `SyntaxWarning` here:
https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/blob/5cd2b1cc50d8714a7b6a84f167983767e24d2761/Lib/fontTools/cffLib/specializer.py#L44C1-L45C1

See also https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.12.html#other-language-changes

comment.body: in https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/commit/4b73a17e0cc28b8128eff14a6e03318623bc66e3, I had already added the `r` for raw strings so the invalid escape sequence was ignored. Can you rebase off main branch and get rid of the `r"""`, since you're using an emoji now?

issue.title: [TTX] head table flags bit1 disappearing when converting back to TTF
issue.body:
process:
1. `ttx font.ttf`
2. modify a value in the glyf table
3. `ttx font.ttx`

head table before:
`<flags value="00000000 00001011"/>`
head table after:
`<flags value="00000000 00001001"/>`

For what I tested, it happens only for italic fonts wether I modify the TTX file or not. So my guess is that there is a reason for that but I don't it and the designer of the font doesn't like that data was lost.

-- 
I did this to fix this issue:
```
vttLib.VTTLibInvalidComposite: Component 1 in 'uacute' has wrong x offset: expected 309, found 305. (Bold Italic)
vttLib.VTTLibInvalidComposite: Component 1 in 'uacute' has wrong y offset: expected -5, found -9. (Bold Italic)
vttLib.VTTLibInvalidComposite: Component 1 in 'ugrave' has wrong x offset: expected 309, found 305. (Bold Italic)
vttLib.VTTLibInvalidComposite: Component 1 in 'ugrave' has wrong y offset: expected -5, found -9. (Bold Italic)
```

Files to replicate the process: 
[files.zip](https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/files/13164044/files.zip)

issue.title: [TTX] head table flags bit1 disappearing when converting back to TTF
issue.body:
process:
1. `ttx font.ttf`
2. modify a value in the glyf table
3. `ttx font.ttx`

head table before:
`<flags value="00000000 00001011"/>`
head table after:
`<flags value="00000000 00001001"/>`

For what I tested, it happens only for italic fonts wether I modify the TTX file or not. So my guess is that there is a reason for that but I don't it and the designer of the font doesn't like that data was lost.

-- 
I did this to fix this issue:
```
vttLib.VTTLibInvalidComposite: Component 1 in 'uacute' has wrong x offset: expected 309, found 305. (Bold Italic)
vttLib.VTTLibInvalidComposite: Component 1 in 'uacute' has wrong y offset: expected -5, found -9. (Bold Italic)
vttLib.VTTLibInvalidComposite: Component 1 in 'ugrave' has wrong x offset: expected 309, found 305. (Bold Italic)
vttLib.VTTLibInvalidComposite: Component 1 in 'ugrave' has wrong y offset: expected -5, found -9. (Bold Italic)
```

Files to replicate the process: 
[files.zip](https://github.com/fonttools/fonttools/files/13164044/files.zip)

comment.body:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/typography/opentype/spec/head

> Bit 1: Left sidebearing point at x=0 (relevant only for TrueType rasterizers)

it means your font is claiming one thing ("left sidebearing point at x=0") but it's doing something else. When recomputing the bounding boxes upon compile, fonttools detects that some glyphs's left sidebearings are not actually at 0 and if any glyph's bbox.xMin != lsb, then the bit should _not_ be set.

If you want fonttools not to touch that, try use `ttx -b`, it should not attempt to recalc the bounding boxes but use the value from the .ttx file as is

issue.title: [feaLib] allow compiling features to existing layout tables?
issue.body:
In FontForge when compiling a feature file to a font, it does not overwrite existing layout tables but amends the new features to them (unlike makeotf and feaLib). This is really very convenient to e.g. add a new feature to an existing fonts without having to dump all existing layout tables to feature syntax then apply them again. I use it also to have separate files for different scripts, so that I can have `languagesystem` statements without registering all features in the font to all language systems (the alternative of explicitly adding `script` and `language` statements to each feature is cumbersome to write).

I don’t know yet how hard is it to extend feaLib to do this, but if this kind of feature is acceptable I’ll give it a try.

comment.body: Yes, this is very useful for adding `chws / vchw`: https://github.com/kojiishi/east_asian_spacing/issues/175#issuecomment-1777089788
